Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "powershellgallery not responding and fails when attempting install-module" (#8304) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Received 500 error when attempting to open PowerShellGallery.com (specifically https://www.powershellgallery.com/package/AzureAD) to obtain package. This has been reproducing for about 12 hours at this point. The entire site is almost entirely unresponsive.  Checking the status page at https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellGallery/blob/master/psgallery_status.md#powershell-gallery-status shows "The PowerShell Gallery is currently: Experiencing an outage" but the most current/recent entry with details about an outage is from October 15th.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Migrate nuget-build feed from myget to Azure DevOps" (#8305) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: For: NuGet/Engineering#2909

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][Reflow]Some of the contents under the select packages is getting overlapped when reflow is applied" (#8190) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1188114
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ​

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450) 


## Repro Steps:

    Change the Display resolution to 1280*1024 in System display settings
    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "Open Profile drop down" and press enter
    Tab till "API Keys" and Press enter
    Tab till "Create button" and press enter
    Apply reflow
    Check whether data is overlapping is observed or not  

## Actual Results:

Some of the contents under the select packages is getting overlapped when reflow is applied 
## Expected Results:
User should be able to view the data without overlapping and all the information should be visible clearly with one scrollbar after applying reflow
## User Impact:
Users will not be able to understand the information if it gets overlapped in reflow

## Notes
This is in reference to the section in Create Key that shows example glob patterns. You do not have to change display resolution to see this. It is sufficient to shrink the window to minimum width and zoom in until the overlap occurs
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11051729/92165397-d8e1de00-edeb-11ea-9bd8-7ce5bde30820.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][Contrast]Color contrast for the focus on icons Facebook and Twitter with background is 1.658 which is less than 3:1" (#8185) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1184494
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ​

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450)


## Repro Steps:

    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "Packages tab" item and press enter
    Tab till any package and press enter.
    Tab till "Share" section
    Check whether the color contrast for the background to focus on the icons "Facebook" and "Twitter" greater than or equal to 3:1

## Actual Results:

Color contrast for the focus on icons Facebook and Twitter with background is 1.658 which is less than 3:1

   
## Expected Results:
Color contrast for the focus on icons Facebook and Twitter with background is 1.658 it should be greater than or equal to 3:1
## User Impact:
Users with low vision would face difficulty to identify the elements if the non-text contrast is less than 3:1

## Notes
We don't control these icons. I don't know if we are allowed to/should change them.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[A11y][WCAG2.1][Contrast]The color contrast ratio for the stars under "Stars" column is < 3:1" (#8286) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1069750

# Environment Details:
#URL:https://www.nuget.org/​
 ​
## OS Details:​
Windows 10 Version 1909 Build 18363.657​
​
## Browser and Version:​
Chromium Edge Version 80.0.361.51​
​
# Repro Steps:​
1.Hit the URL "https://www.nuget.org" 
2.Tab till "Packages" link in the top navigation and press enter​
3.Tab till any existing package and press enter​
4.Tab till "GitHub Usage" section and press enter​
5.Using color contrast analyzer, verify the color contrast ratio for the stars under "Stars" column header
​
## Actual Result:​
The color contrast ratio for the stars under "Stars" column is 2.51:1 which is < 3:1

## Expected Result:​
The color contrast ratio for non-text content should be >= 3:1
​
## User Impact:​
Users with visual impairments will find it difficult to access the content
​
# Notes:
Depending on how these stars are rendered, this will either be very simple, or very not simple.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ".NET 5.0 not .NETFramework 5.0" (#8235) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
When viewing dependencies on the web site for a package that targets .NET 5.0 the UI reads '.NETFramework 5.0' which I believe is incorrect.

### To Reproduce
Publish a package that targets .NET 5.0

### Expected behavior
Should display ".NET 5.0" instead of ".NETFramework 5.0"

### Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16097639/95006735-9f2d0e80-0607-11eb-8b15-d3be2f25a535.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dependencies not showing platform component of .NET 5 TFM" (#8268) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The gallery is only showing `NetCoreApp 5.0` under the dependencies node and not `net5.0-windows10.19041`. 

I have a package that multi-targets both `net5.0` and `net5.0-windows10.19041`. I'd expect both to show up on the website; they are distinct dependency groups in the NuSpec:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1427284/96260782-7acd1c80-0f8d-11eb-8394-678d2728b471.png)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Ability to restrict nuget package to specific feed" (#10214) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
(_or one possible way NuGet could improve the `dotnet restore` story around failed sources_)

I understand that the current behavior is by design (#7035, #7015, #6373) and I'm proposing improvements to it.

---

Today the all of our builds were broken because of 

1.) `dotnet restore` requires that every single package source to be accessible

**and**

2.) [MyGet had an outage](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/177608/97761649-03e36800-1ae5-11eb-8853-8c740bf69b19.png) that lasted several hours (still out as of this writing)

---

In my scenario, all nuget packages come from nuget.org except for 1 (one) single package that comes from a vendor - that happens to be hosted in a MyGet private feed. I tried to add one more dependency (from nuget.org) but because MyGet was down, I got an error:

```
NuGet.targets(128,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://www.myget.org/F/vendor/api/v3/index.json
```

My `.csproj` was changed from something like this:

```xml
<ItemGroup>
  <PackageReference Include="Serilog" Version="2.10.0" />
  <PackageReference Include="VendorPackage" Version="1.2.3" />
</ItemGroup>
```

To something like this:

```xml
<ItemGroup>
  <PackageReference Include="AutoMapper" Version="10.1.1" />
  <PackageReference Include="Serilog" Version="2.10.0" />
  <PackageReference Include="VendorPackage" Version="1.2.3" />
</ItemGroup>
```

As you can see, all I've done was to add a new dependency (that would be found only in nuget.org).

I had done a `dotnet restore` previously so both `Serilog` and `VendorPackage` were already in the local nuget cache (along with their own dependencies), and the newly added package `AutoMapper` in this example needed to be restored from nuget.org.

Now, there seems to be a couple of issues here that I don't fully understand:

1.) Why does nuget need to try to access any on-line package sources, if I'm asking for VendorPackage v1.2.3 and it's already in the local cache along with all of its dependencies?

I would understand the need to check for new versions if I used a wildcard in the version number e.g. `<PackageReference Include="VendorPackage" Version="1.2.*" />` but I didn't... I have a very specific and hard-coded version there... That should be enough.

2.) Why does nuget need to search for the package in every single source? Again, I declared `AutoMapper v10.1.1` that exists in the local nuget cache, and was found in nuget.org. Why doesn't it stop with the first feed that satisfy the hard-coded version requirement?

---

### Proposal

Regardless of the answers to the questions above, I believe the `dotnet restore` experience would improve a lot of we could define which feed(s) should be searched for each package.

A new attribute on `PackageReference` e.g. `Feed` could allow one or more names (CSV) of package sources that are defined in the nuget configuration (machine/local).

e.g.

.csproj
```xml
<ItemGroup>
  <PackageReference Include="AutoMapper" Version="10.1.1" Feed="nuget.org" />
  <PackageReference Include="VendorPackage" Version="1.2.3" Feed="vendor" />
</ItemGroup>
```

nuget.config
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<configuration>
  <packageSources>
    <clear />
    <add key="nuget.org" value="https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json" />
    <add key="vendor" value="https://www.myget.org/F/vendor/api/v3/index.json" />
  </packageSources>
  <disabledPackageSources>
    <clear />
  </disabledPackageSources>
  <fallbackPackageFolders>
    <clear />
  </fallbackPackageFolders>
</configuration>
```

---

### Verbose Logs

```
C:\project>dotnet restore
  Determining projects to restore...
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.Utils\Project.Utils.csproj (in 386 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.ApiModels\Project.ApiModels.csproj (in 386 ms).
  Restored C:\project\test\Project.Api.IntegrationTests\Project.Api.IntegrationTests.csproj (in 632 ms).
  Restored C:\project\test\Project.Utils.UnitTests\Project.Utils.UnitTests.csproj (in 639 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.Utils.Excel\Project.Utils.Excel.csproj (in 727 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.DataModels.Migrations\Project.DataModels.Migrations.csproj (in 780 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.DataModels\Project.DataModels.csproj (in 786 ms).
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.1.403\NuGet.targets(128,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://www.myget.org/F/vendor/api/v3/index.json. [C:\project\project.sln]
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.1.403\NuGet.targets(128,5): error :   Response status code does not indicate success: 503 (Service Unavailable). [C:\project\project.sln]
```

---

```
.NET Core SDK (reflecting any global.json):
 Version:   3.1.403
 Commit:    9e895200cd

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     Windows
 OS Version:  10.0.18363
 OS Platform: Windows
 RID:         win10-x64
 Base Path:   C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.1.403\

Host (useful for support):
  Version: 3.1.9
  Commit:  774fc3d6a9
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Ability to restrict nuget package to specific feed" (#10214) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
(_or one possible way NuGet could improve the `dotnet restore` story around failed sources_)

I understand that the current behavior is by design (#7035) and I'm proposing improvements to it.

---

Today the all of our builds were broken because of 

1.) `dotnet restore` requires that every single package source to be accessible

**and**

2.) [MyGet had an outage](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/177608/97761649-03e36800-1ae5-11eb-8853-8c740bf69b19.png) that lasted several hours (still out as of this writing)

```

</ItemGroup>
```

  <PackageReference Include="VendorPackage" Version="1.2.3" />
</ItemGroup>

I had done a `dotnet restore` previously so both `Serilog` and `VendorPackage` were already in the local nuget cache (along with their own dependencies), and the newly added package `AutoMapper` in this example needed to be restored from nuget.org.

Now, there seems to be a couple of issues here that I don't fully understand:

1.) Why does nuget need to try to access any on-line package sources, if I'm asking for VendorPackage v1.2.3 and it's already in the local cache along with all of its dependencies?

    <add key="vendor" value="https://www.myget.org/F/vendor/api/v3/index.json" />
  </packageSources>
  <disabledPackageSources>
    <clear />
  </disabledPackageSources>
  <fallbackPackageFolders>
    <clear />
  </fallbackPackageFolders>
</configuration>
```

---

### Verbose Logs

```
C:\project>dotnet restore
  Determining projects to restore...
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.Utils\Project.Utils.csproj (in 386 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.ApiModels\Project.ApiModels.csproj (in 386 ms).
  Restored C:\project\test\Project.Api.IntegrationTests\Project.Api.IntegrationTests.csproj (in 632 ms).
  Restored C:\project\test\Project.Utils.UnitTests\Project.Utils.UnitTests.csproj (in 639 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.Utils.Excel\Project.Utils.Excel.csproj (in 727 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.DataModels.Migrations\Project.DataModels.Migrations.csproj (in 780 ms).
  Restored C:\project\src\Project.DataModels\Project.DataModels.csproj (in 786 ms).
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.1.403\NuGet.targets(128,5): error : Unable to load the service index for source https://www.myget.org/F/vendor/api/v3/index.json. [C:\project\project.sln]
C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\3.1.403\NuGet.targets(128,5): error :   Response status code does not indicate success: 503 (Service Unavailable). [C:\project\project.sln]
```

```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Validate Search branch before merging into Dev" (#10213) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "PM UI:  selecting projects in a solution-level context is slow" (#10112) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Repro steps:
1.  Open the NuGet.Client solution (https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client).
2.  In Solution Explorer right-click on the solution and select "Manage NuGet Packages for Solution..."
3.  In PM UI switch to the Browse tab.
4   Select a package.
5.  In the right-hand details pane check the checkbox for all projects.

Expected result:  The action will complete nearly instantaneously.
Actual result:  The action takes ~2 seconds to complete in 16.8.  In 16.7 (and the release-5.6.x branch instead of dev) it's nearly instantaneous.

This appears to be the result of heavy asyncification with JTF.  We should consider batching as a tool in improving performance.

This is partially affected by https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10094.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "A lot of the restore coverage relies on project.json instead of PackageReference tests" (#10212) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
These 2 are largely equivalent in the core restore part, but there are some slight differences. 
We should move these tests to PR.

Related: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10211

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Add metadata to restore tests, make them go through the no-op codepath" (#10211) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
While I investigating https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10068, I hit an known problem of the no-op codepath not being exercised in a good amount of unit test. 

The reason is that the packagespec is not created with the same amount of details prod package spec would be.
In prod scenarios, all restores go through the restorerunner which calls https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/c3219e49852add8371db25680a300cce5551ef00/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Commands/RestoreCommand/Utility/SpecValidationUtility.cs#L28 to validate that things like the `RestoreMedata` are not null or empty.

Now this is not a major problem for no-op, I have not discovered any regressions because of this, but it *does* not reflect what the actual restore code run is.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PM UI:  performance of installing package to solution has regressed" (#10210) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
In VS 2019 16.7.6 it took ~17.5 minutes to install [System.Ben 1.0.1](https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Ben/1.0.1) to all 82 projects in the NuGet.Client solution.
```
Time Elapsed: 00:17:27.1112177
========== Finished ==========
```
In VS 2019 16.9 P2 it took ~27 minutes to install.
```
Time Elapsed: 00:27:18.8386891
========== Finished ==========
```
Not only is 17 minutes too long to begin with, but the 10- minute regression is even worse.

I haven't investigated yet, so it's unclear exactly when the regression occurred; however, the CodeSpaces work in 16.8 is a reasonable first guess.

CC @rrelyea, @sbanni

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Item template is no longer visible after adding Asset elements" (#8957) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
- After adding the `Asset` elements for nuget packages. The template is no longer listed in list of available item to add to projects.

- I also don't understand why do I need to set `repositoryId` in template properties to VSIX project id, essentially creating circular dependency between those project. 

- The "2. Place your `nupkg` files in a folder called `Packages` within the VSIX." instruction is also not clear. Is putting the folder in file system enough? Do I need to also include it in the project definition? Should I copy it to output directory or set the files as resources? 
- Where exactly do I put the `<Reference ...>` element mentioned in "Best practices"?


---
#### Document Details

⚠ *Do not edit this section. It is required for docs.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.*

* ID: bbf9be6a-e7b0-b9b6-a3e8-8b5de3c6900d
* Version Independent ID: c12505c9-6f14-7111-2578-5c2664b4515d
* Content: [NuGet Packages in Visual Studio templates](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/visual-studio-extensibility/visual-studio-templates)
* Content Source: [docs/visual-studio-extensibility/Visual-Studio-Templates.md](https://github.com/NuGet/docs.microsoft.com-nuget/blob/master/docs/visual-studio-extensibility/Visual-Studio-Templates.md)
* Product: **nuget**
* GitHub Login: @karann-msft
* Microsoft Alias: **karann**

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VS:  logging should indicate target project in start of package operation" (#10209) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Installing a package to a solution (like NuGet.Client) yields output similar to the following partial output in the Package Manager output window pane:
```
...
Installing NuGet package System.Ben 1.0.1.
Committing restore...
Writing assets file to disk. Path: E:\git\NuGet.Client.Test\artifacts\NuGet.Versioning\16.0\obj\project.assets.json
Successfully installed 'System.Ben 1.0.1' to NuGet.Versioning
Executing nuget actions took 3.51 sec
Installing NuGet package System.Ben 1.0.1.
Committing restore...
Writing assets file to disk. Path: E:\git\NuGet.Client.Test\artifacts\NuGet.Frameworks\16.0\obj\project.assets.json
Successfully installed 'System.Ben 1.0.1' to NuGet.Frameworks
Executing nuget actions took 1.94 sec
...
```
While end of installation indicates the target project (via assets file), the start of installation does not.

This log line:
```
Installing NuGet package System.Ben 1.0.1.
```
...would be improved if it mentioned the target project (or assets file):
```
Installing NuGet package System.Ben 1.0.1 to project NuGet.Versioning.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS 2019:  unable to install signed packages behind firewall" (#10193) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
A customer is unable to install signed packages in VS 2019 due to the network restrictions preventing X.509 chain building/revocation checking that is part of signed package validation.  

I created this issue on behalf of the customer.
